comments.commentBody:
An appropriate puzzle for Friday, and a really great blog to learn from -- many thanks to all who commented.

That said, I think the clue posted for 13d should have been "facility to sense orientation", given that it is a portmanteau word.

Cow Pasture -  So let's say it's all true and PSU wanted it's football money (by the way, in the mid-80's Beaver Stadium held approx 90,000 fans... and two National it's now about 107,000... with 2 National Championships....) you don't think that their football program could have helped develop the Big East, with Syracuse, BC WVU and Pitt (by the way Pitt did vote against PSU joining)... into a supreme eastern sports conference?  Actually, it was the Big East who was greedy in the short term was it not?
I don't understand why "field opening?" is "citi". What is "citifield"?

I spent the longest time convinced that "Play furniture?" was a CAMEO ROLE. That blocked the lower left corner in a most frustrating manner for way too long. Finally saw the light. Re: lindamurgap@#2, I too was buzzing a little, but mine was a martini. It also didn't help that I had just worn myself out cracking the leftover Friday puzzle.

It was clear from the moment Arod WON the biggest contract in sports history that certain folks would grind their teeth. As he's DEMONSTRATED unmatched talent showing his worth, grinding of teeth rolled into savage "criticism," especially that masked in "journalism" like this very subtle and articulate article. It sounds cynical, but it's reality: a man of color shattering just about all adored records with an unprecedented talent-based performance will never be held in a positive light. When Arod demonstrated, unlike just about any of the "greats" before him, that he is a sensible man, again another opportunity for "criticism" to sliver in, with obvious hopes that he'd crack. Well, there's the first world series title. Keep on heckling in your subtle, articulate ways. Keep on grinding your teeth. We know you are. Arod makes it official in baseball like Jordan in basketball that only in imagined little scenarios like Rocky-Apollo Creed will there be any hope of talents like Arod failing.

I am wondering if we are all getting our collective legs pulled. After re-reading comment #5 I used the Google language tool to determine that "piccolo brufolo" is the Italian for a small pimple, and, further, the etymology of ziti is a tad convoluted. The most charming one I found is this:

Etymology: Italian, plural of zito "a piece of tubular pasta," probably short for maccheroni di zita, literally, "bride's macaroni".

To KarmaSartre, therefore: per la vergogna!

I am a diehard Red Sox fan, so I am biased. But A-Rod pulls this kind of stuff, and then tries to spin it. Well, the pitcher shouldn't complain--he's only won a handful of games. He said the same thing about Bronson Arroyo when slapping the ball out of Arroyo's glove during the 2004 ALCS. He also said initially that he thought it was a neat idea that almost worked. Then he tried to defend yelling "Ha!" when an opposing player tried to catch a fly ball.

Ben Shpigel, there may seemingly be a lot of unwritten rules in baseball to you. But A-rod's been in the major for many, many years now. He should know better.

Clearly this guy thinks he's above the rules. I think his ex-wife could tell you about that.

Don't spin this, Ben. A-rod didn't make a mistake or forget. He's still an arrogant, classless clown.

If you've ever played the game of baseball at any serious level, you would know that you don't run across the pitcher's mound. In fact, no one but the pitcher generally touches it during the game. Imagine a catcher between pitches and when the batter steps out of the box sweeping the batter's "ditch" with his cleat. It would never happen, and if it did, would probably nearly immediately precipitate a fight. If it's no unwritten rule, then why would a class act like Keith Hernandez say that he'd never do it?

No way A-Rod was right in this case. I could see him simply being absent-minded, or simply moronic about it, but I don't see him being clever or foolish enough to do this on purpose. I think he was lazy, disrespectful and totally bush-league in this, no different than "Ha" and his wussy glove slap in Boston.

Imagine him running across the mound when Josh Beckett or Roy Halladay were pitching? Wouldn't happen.
I can't find another adjective at the moment for Alex other than "slimey."  Fits him perfectly.  I don't think he relishes being hated, though--deep down, he's big, spoiled baby.

I have had no use for Alex Rodriguez since I saw him try to slap the ball out of I think it was a pitcher's (maybe a first baseman's) hand while running to first base during an All Star game a few years ago.  He was out on the play because he did not succeed in knocking the ball loose.  But I have considered him to be a cheater ever since.  I am surprised that incident is not recounted with the others from 2004 and 2007, which I did not know about until this flap.  I hate it that Rodriquez gets so much coverage by the media when he shows such poor sportsmanship as an athlete.

I'd recommend before getting a set of expensive name-brand clubs, custom fit, try going to a club builder, who uses less expensive components, and have that fit to you. If that works, then you can transfer the measurements to a more expensive set, or not. It's up to you, but you'll spend less, and be able to do more tweaking with a set of less expensive components from a club builder.

If the mark of a too-easy Saturday puzzle is that I can solve it, then this puzzle is guilty as charged. But it didn't feel easy to me. Indeed, my experience of it was so like Patrick's that I have little to add by way of reaction. I was, however, familiar with COZEN; I've encountered it some few times in my reading, though I can't remember in what contexts. ALANA, OLEN, KIBEI, SKALD, and LEO XI, on the other hand, were new to me. "Fat"/SLIM was a hoot.

Lots of credit to Mr. Heilman for lacing his puzzle with clever, entertaining, but fair clues.
DrW --  Yes, I was pulling.

If its doctors they're looking for, perhaps Republicans could resurrect their former senate majority leader, Doctor Bill Frist to tell them what ails the country. After all, he once claimed to be able to diagnose a comatose patient by looking at a videotape of her breathing and decided that he knew better than her own doctors whose only advantage was that they were in the room with her and could perform, you know, actual medical tests.

This same Bill Frist must be quite unhappy these days since his only real job while in the senate was to look out for his family's HMO business and make sure no one got within shouting distance of health care reform. Still, when duty called, that is, the need to throw a sop to the GOP's ultra-right Christian supporters, he did his job and pronounced Terry Schiavo ready to awaken at any moment and denounced her husband, her doctors and anyone who disagreed as somehow satanic.

The GOP, who claim, like Mitch McConnell and Jim Bunning, to want smaller government only mean that when it comes to helping actual real people. Which is why Bunning earlier this year blocked unemployment checks to people who had lost their jobs because he and McConnell and the rest of the Republican cohort had let laissez-faire turn into laissez-unfair while allowing Wall Street to run off with the family jewels while handing the bill to those who had just been robbed. Big government is fine as long as it benefits the ultra rich and corporate robber barons.

Republicans are bereft of ideas, devoid of morals, and unavailable for any kind of bipartisan effort to lead the country away from the malaise they and their great leaders Bush and Cheney created.

At least they can take credit for creating something.

Well, since everyone is (justifiably) disenchanted with the choices for Congress from the political world, maybe we can import some candidates from other professions. Perhaps someone from a field that has demonstrated a lot of success over the past couple of years, like Wall Street? Or maybe a star athlete, like a preeminent professional golfer or a super bowl quarterback...? A mining executive, perchance? The two doctors in Kentucky certainly represent effective cost containment in their profession, right?

It is discouraging and unfortunate, but it does seem like neither party really deserves to win. I think this is the natural result of years of pandering to partisanship and parochialism. Sensationalism instead of statemanship. A nominating/primary system that excludes the influence of the independants in the middle.

I am very disappointed that for whatever reasons, Obama's goals of postpartisanship and cooperation seem to have not worked out so well, so far. Perhaps it is not too late to start.

We ought to be very grateful for your sense of humor because it so easy to sink into despair over the state of what passes for politics today.

Speaking of despair, it was only today that I learned both "Bill Moyers Journal" and "Now" were going off the air at the end of this month. I can't imagine life without them! The state of television is almost as bad as the state of politics, and those two shows gave me hope that investigative journalism and reasoned debate are still possible.

Bill Moyers ended this week's Journal on a note of optimism, so I'll try to pass a little of it on. Yes, the clowns have taken over center stage, but there are still serious, intelligent people at work whom we hear very little about. Among them are Moyers' two guests-- FCC Commissioner Michael Copps, whose calm demeanor belies his passion for ensuring communication and information are accessible to all citizens, and William K. Black, an associate professor of law and economics at the University of Missouri-Kansas City, who spoke with the same sort of controlled passion for bank regulation. It was also on the Journal that I first heard Elizabeth Warren speak, and many others whose names I don't remember, but who influenced me greatly and gave me hope that there are a lot of smart, compassionate people in this country whom we never hear about. Their Q scores may be off-the-charts low, but they're out there, working hard. Let's take some consolation in that.

..."The Democratic nominee may be the lieutenant governor, Daniel Mongiardo, the same guy who Bunning called Saddam-like six years ago. If he and Paul are both the final candidates, it will be an all-physician Senate election. You do see more and more doctors in the political game. Perhaps they want to get out of the medical business before that payment-by-chicken thing kicks in."

Geez, Gail, why didn't you tell us this from the get-go? An all-physician Senate election? What will they promise--free colonoscopies for all at the voting booth--who vote for the DOCTOR? And, P.S., you can just forget about the chickens!

The problem with most doctors is that they are technicians--not politicians or humanists. The country needs more of the latter. Technicians can work on improving Twitter--and finding better material to replace hips and knees, and anti-biotics that are not resistent! Also, I doubt it is Primary Care doctors who are running! They are too busy seeing patients and fighting for better patient care.

The most famous doctor in the Senate, Tom Coburn, has been much too busy being the go-between in paying off his colleague, John Ensign's mistress and her family, to think about patient-care. And he was one of the loonies who talked about death panels! YIKES!

Let's see: what other doctors do we have. Howard Dean does not count, because he is a responsible, concerned doctor who favors the Single Payer healthcare system. Besides, he was defeated! Then there is Bill Frist (fortunately an ex-senator) who diagnosed Terry Shaiavo in a coma as being able to recover--thereby stopping her family's efforts to let her die in peace. Oh, did I mention--he NEVER SAW HER! He diagnosed by Ouiji board, no doubt--and his religious "convictions."

I am not saying we need to be saved from doctors, but that would be a good start in the political world! We need doctors to do what they have been trained for--caring for sick people! We do not need the greed of far too many of them--the fat cats, as it were--at the political bargainning table!

Ms Collins again reminds us why we miss Molly Ivins so much; but threaded through her customary whimsy is a terribly important message - conveyed in the title given to her column today. The nominations in both of the major parties (why use that phrase when there are exactly zero minor parties?) are controlled, almost without exception, state by state and district by district, by the party bosses. I don't know personally any of them in this corner of the Empire State, but for the most part they completely (I do mean completely) make clear that they lack the one thing we need more than any other right now - IMAGINATION.

I guess it takes years and years to get to be a party boss - especially at the county and state level - and those years take a toll - they suck the blood out of even the best of 'em. Almost all of them recognize only one "virtue" - electability - and they are as often as not wrong about even that.

"Running on Empty?" That doesn't convey even a hint of the depth of the trouble we are in in 2010.

As a young, unmarried adult, on a number of occasions I watched friends play poker.

One lesson I learned, was that if one person had a bad hand, typically everyone had poor hands. Likewise, if someone had a good hand, play was cautious since it was likely everyone had a pretty good hand.

That observation seems to apply to this situation. Apparently this is the round for Republican poor hands.

A lot of it stems from the fact that primary elections are starting to take place while the public is still inflamed about their situation. Come November, however, the Democrats are going to have a credible list of accomplishments and about eighty percent of the employable American population will have much less anxiety about their employment.

The Republican candidates, however, will have a much less substantial record of accomplishments, and through the camera lens, their supporters in the background may be a serious PR challenge.

Both parties may have hopeless candidates but at least the Democrats are not trying to changes horses in mid-stream. The Republicans are trying to change horses in mid-stream - with inexperienced horses.

If the Republicans don't do well, the Democrats had better work to work to better their hands the next time around because it's for certain the Republicans will.

I finally concluded the Democrats were hopeless this past Thursday when Chuck Schumer said his party had learned a lesson about not responding to GOP lies during the recent health care debate.

You mean they didn't get a clue when Schumer's colleague, the hapless John Kerry, saw his Vietnam War heroism trashed by the Swift Boat gang in 2004? And what about the lies told about another Vietnam War hero Max Cleland by Republicans in 2002? And what about Whitewater? And Willie Horton? And on and on.

Yes, Gail, the Democrats are hopeless. I agree. But at least they're not sociopaths.
there are no real choices only hair styles.
well, others may want to parse this for political insight, but I just laughed out loud at your last line - thanks for that.

In Florida, Governor Charlie Crist's biggest mistake was not appointing himself to the office that he really wanted (senator), which he could have done after Martinez resigned.  Now we're gonna be stuck with tea bagging wanna-be Marco Rubio simply because the electorate has decided that it wants the most extreme right wing non-incumbant on the ballot.  As a black Democrat, Kendrick (the) Meek is not going to inherit the earth, the wind, fire, water or any political office in Florida.  Yeah, it's certainly hopeless in this state.

Too bad we get one year of governance and then one of electioneering. Still, I can't think that "tea party" Republicans (must we Capitalize that?)will ultimately sink that party. Aren't we all a tad smarter than that? So Democrats need to really come out strong. It's handed to them on a platter. Let's hope they rally. We have to end this plutocracy and restore a democracy. As in the wealthiest pay the most taxes, not the least. As in all receive great health care for modest sums. As in our children get a quality higher education without jeopardizing their entire productive years trying to pay off the student loans. How did we get so far behind the rest of the world?? Why do American kill their fellow citizens at far higher rates than any other country? Why is America the only "first world" country with more than 50% of its people in poverty? So what do any of the candidates have to offer? Let's hear them. Ummm.

While it is unfortunately true that politics makes for strange bed-fellows, the incestuous in-breeding of America's politics has apparently resulted in a unique evolutionary development of brain-dead polyester suited robots. In one of the two permitted parties, these robots all act synchronously and in lemming fashion have already gone over a cliff, but Wily Coyote-style they haven't quit spinning long enough to note they are following gravity's command. The other party, in its usual manner, fractiously follows each their own drummer, many towards the honey-pots of corruption, others to decent intentions, but mostly bumping into one another imagining it is a sign of solidarity.
Taken together these two parties seem to suggest that that young Frenchman studying prisons here was correct in his conclusion that our form of so-called "democracy in America" would result in mob-rule from the lowest common denominator. And we have some very low denominators. Many run for office.
